Well then, what is your basis for morality? On what basis can you say that these acts are absolutely morally wrong? Do you acknowledge that this same dehumanization is done to those in the womb?
 My basis for morality? I treat morality economically, as the exercise of personal autonomy that each individual makes to maximize the interests of themselves and the interests of the group or community in which they participate. In my opinion the puzzle of the Prisoner's Dilemma stands as a simplified model of moral action, where cooperation is required between agents to satisfy these conditions. 
 
 This means that I do not regard morality as absolute in the sense of being unconditional. Moral goodness is conditional upon the interests of the individual and upon their group. However there are events that are not right and can never be right, but these events are not such because they are absolute in the unconditional sense. Rather, these 'intrinisically wrong' events are wrong because there will always be a better alternative no matter the conditions. 
 
 Likewise some events can never be wrong because either we cannot choose worse or because there is no choice in the matter. When we model possible states of the world economically in this fashion (to the appropriate level of resolution), we can mechanically derive a set of values such that we may objectively know what is necessarily right, necessarily wrong, and what may be right or wrong depending on the case. I'd like to point out that this moral theory allows us to evaluate moral action according to both 'absolute' and situational criteria.
 
 I say that authoritarianism and totalitarianism are always wrong, absolutely wrong, because they subordinate the interests of the individual to that of the group rather than holding those interests in well-balanced tension. Unless this tension is maintained the interests of individuals will be contravened such that resulting states of the world will be worse than otherwise. 
 
 When you ask if I "acknowledge" that babies are dehumanized by abortion, I must answer that they are. The fact that babies are dehumanized, deprived of agency, by abortion must be considered in a particular context though. In the context of a free and open society in which abortion is the choice of the mother, this dehumanization must be permitted as the cost of avoid worse dehumanization of both babies, mothers, and possibly others.
 
 Depriving a woman of the legal option to abort her child is worse than allowing her the legal option to abort her child, because it dehumanizes the mother by denying her personal autonomy over her body, and will not avoid the dehumanization of the babies subject to illegal abortions and the dehumanization of those women who may be killed or maimed by such procedures (notably even more dangerous than legal abortions), and so on. There are also much potential danger in the political consequences of allowing such paternalism, particularly in the gradual slide towards authoritarian and totalitarian political states, but that's very much secondary to the immediate consequences for women.
 
 I think that everything should be done to make abortion a woman's last resort, as I abhore the practice and agree that it is morally costly. It would be better if abortions didn't happen, but prohibiting them is worse.

 I don't think all men suck. I am aware there are men who love their children. There are even men who love children who aren't theirs. For this I am more grateful than you know. My son has had the best mentor and male role model on the planet the past four years.
 
 Half of my two best friends is male. Most of my local pals are male since I hang out with musicians. And I should not have to tell a guy who has 23+ years bass experience the male to female ratio in the music world - especially rock and roll. 
 
 However, some men need to be kicked to the curb. That was the case with my ex. I tried to raise my son with him. He was a cheap, abusive XXXXX. And the fact remains that dead beat dads are a problem. People, and in particular men, walk on their kids all too frequently. 
 
 Regardless of your stand on abortion and your reasons for that stand - banning abortion will not suddenly increase responsibility in men or women. Only education and a consience will do that.
 
 I am all about reducing abortion through helping women and working at the root of the problem. Legislation will just make it invisiable to the weak bellied. 
 I know where my line in the sand is - a pregnancy that threatens my health, life or livlihood will be ended - regardless of law. All women have their line in the sand. 
 
 Demonizing a woman for being sexual or not wanting to be a mother is a poor way to encourage women to be responsible or to have any self esteem.
 
 You also scoff at feminism. And although I have no patience for the extremes of any issue, feminism is not an evil. The other extreme makes men the focus of women's lives. We have GOT to stop teaching girls this. A good relationship with a good man can be a wonderful part of your life - but we teach girls that it is their life. As long as we keep attachment to men as a measuring stick for the success of a woman - it will lead to sex. It's incredible what I have seen women put up with just they aren't stuck with the stigma of being single. They have sex with a guy to keep the guy and harbor the illusion that a loser will suddenly be a winner when faced with fatherhood. 
 
 We waste energy, time and money fighting about a law that won't work when there are better ways to address this.
 
 And by the way - I was there when my mom was pregnant, several of my friends were pregnant, and have witnessed two births. Not the same as being pregnant or giving birth - I assure you. But really that is easy part - just wait until they start talking back.
